description.narrative:
Background and context The overall problem is economic inequality, the lack of opportunities for generating income and sustenance in marginalized communities. This is an important problem in Mexico, where 43.6% of the population lives in poverty,and 7.6%live in extreme poverty—of which 73% are members of indigenous groups (CONEVAL, 2019); and according to recent estimates as many as 8 million people will have returned to poverty this year as a result of the COVID generated economic recession(CONEVAL, 2021). Economic inclusion will be key in the recovery: 68% of agricultural production units are small farmers, and 17.6% rely on subsistence agricultural production for food (FAO 2018). These subsistence-basedfamily farms are characterized by limited access to productive assets (less than a fifth in value than consolidated family farms), very low education (4.9 years average), and almost no access to credit (only about 3% have access to public financing or other forms of credit) (SAGARPA 2012). In addition to agricultural production, economic inclusion aimed at women and community-based projects considers small artisanal production, and the provision of services—of which community-based tourism is especially relevant (CCMSS 2017, CONABIO 2020).
The specificproblem addressed by this project and our overall strategy is the lack of access to resources for economic and income generating disruptive projects in poor and marginalized communities, and the lack ofaccess to markets by those projects. This means three different types of resources: 1)Knowledge and social capital, which we address by fostering participation, the sharing of experiences and technical assistance resources. 2) Productive assets—including monetary resources—which we address directly, by financing implementation is a subset of projects; and indirectly, by promoting public allocation of resources to projects in marginalized communities. 3) Access to decision-making spaces, whichwe address by enabling direct participation in communities, by women specifically; and by opening up policy dialogue where communities and project leaders can participate, at the local and national level.
The ongoing project, financed by the EU, hasmade resources available to 30 projects in two states directly, and this year, will foster public dialogue on what it means to foster sustainable, disruptive economic inclusion --through creating and engaging authorities in policydialogue to promote public resource allocation for projects like these, and sort out how technical assistance can be developed and shared. Disruptive projects as understood in this context are those that provide basic assets wherenone exist, that ensure the short-term subsistence of projects underway though they may yet not be economically viable,that foster the disruption of public subsidy and supply chain capture, and that ensure community participation.
The project alignswell with Novib’s focus on sustainable income generating projects and value chain development, it is key in the current economic downturn, and will make the best of the research we’ve produced and the evidence we have gathered over the last twoyearsaround what works to make disruptive economic inclusion viable. It complements a broad range of activities underway in OMX to foster economic justice, especially through policies that redistribute towards and engage poor andmarginalized communities. The project will open up a space in which economic, development and sustainability policies are discussed, at the local and national level in Mexico, fostering community participation and formulating specific policy alternatives.
Project goal The overall goal of the project is to promote economic inclusion, access to markets and the economic empowerment of women.
Specific objectives 1. To move the public agenda and build coalitions to make public policy alternatives visible andviable. These are policies that (1) facilitate access to public financing, access to diverse productive inputs and technical assistance that make it possible to give viability and sustainability to initiativesthat build inclusive economic alternatives; (2) facilitate market access for these initiatives; and (3) limit value chain capture and unfair practices. 2. Create support networks, develop capacities and enable horizontal learning processes that foster thelong-termsustainability of initiatives that build inclusive economic alternatives.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam International’s decision to incorporate new members, especially from emerging developing countries, is part of its aim to become a more global, relevant and effective organization to promote social change as a culturally diverse confederation working from several different priority approaches and strategies.
Oxfam Mexico (OM) is the first formal member of the confederation incorporatedthrough this process. As a Mexican organization with a history of its own and links to other Latin American countries, Oxfam Mexicohas joined the confederation with Mexco's perspective of Oxfam's role in the region, hoping to contribute to enrich it.
International cooperation in Latin America and the Caribbean is clearly following a new trend: on one hand, overall funding is being reduced and, on the other, funds are now being channelled to build the States' public policy and institutional capacities. As a result of their economic dynamism, several countries in the region are no longer "poor countries" strictly speaking and have announced overcoming social inequality as their main challenge. They are attempting to transform their social and economic policies seeking to improve the distribution of wealth, rebuild their institutional architecture grounded in democracy and transparency, and establish a new relationship between governments and civil society. In an increasingly interconnected and interdependent world, these changes have stirred the debate over the role played by the region and, in particular, the countries with the most dynamic economies in the world. This situation has changed the perspective of our responsibilities and contribution to the fight to overcome the current global crisisand poverty. Oxfam Mexico has an added value for the work of Oxfam International.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
